Award.AwardTitle: 2016 IEEE Mobile Data Management (MDM 2016) Conference: Student Activities Support; Porto, Portugal; June 13-16, 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation of 20 graduate and undergraduate students enrolled at universities in the U.S. in the 17th IEEE International Conference on Mobile Data Management (MDM 2016), which will be held June 13-16, 2016 in Porto, Portugal (http://mdmconferences.org/mdm2016/). MDM is a premier conference co-sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society. It encompasses all aspects of mobility. Given the broad scope of mobility, MDM brings together researchers from databases, networking and ubiquitous and pervasive computing, to present and discuss the progress of science in these areas of critical national needs. The conference relies on the experience of senior members of the community, but also aims to generate fresh ideas, foster new collaborations, and expose new people to emerging research opportunities. Attendance at MDM is very beneficial to students. The conference makes for an excellent forum for exchange of ideas and future collaborations. Students also have opportunities to meet distinguished researchers and be inspired and mentored by them to follow careers in mobile data management research.

A number of student-oriented events are planned: workshops, demos, panels, seminars, PhD forum, and a special industrial forum. The availability of the travel support will be well publicized throughout the U.S. research community. Students from underrepresented groups (women, minorities and disabled students) are especially encouraged to apply. The project has established processes for selecting the awardees that would both benefit from participating in MDM and contribute to the MDM program, especially the student-oriented activities. The MDM Conference Proceedings are published by IEEE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to provide travel support for students enrolled at universities in the U.S. to attend the 17th IEEE International Conference on Mobile Data Management (MDM 2016), which was held June 13-16, 2016 in Porto, Portugal.  The conference is co-sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society. 

We widely advertised the NSF travel award opportunity through the following forums:dbworld, ubicomp, ukubinet, and SIGIR lists, as well as the following sites/email-lists: SENSORNET@listserv.acm.org, sigmob@acm.org, SIGSIM@acm.org, TCI-ANNOUNCE@computer.org, percom@lists.umbc.edu, info@icstconferences.org, commsoft@ieee.org

The MDM'16 travel award committee, consisting of Gabriel Ghinita (UMass Boston), Sanjay Madria (Missouri University of Science and Technology), and Wang-Chien Li (Penn State U.) carefully reviewed all applications and  selected seven student awardees.

We offered travel support to the following seven students (one woman), all of whom accepted the offer and attended the conference: Jay Ghurye (Univ of Maryland College Park), Xiaoyu Ge (Univ of Pittsburgh), Mihai Maruseac (Univ of Massachusetts Boston), San Yeung (Missouri University of Science and Technology), Qing Guo (University of Illinois at Chicago), Qiwei Han (Univ of Pittsburgh), and Katrina Ward (Missouri University of Science and Technology).

We believe MDM 2016 exposed the students to new ideas and open problems and brought them in contact with the world of potential advisers and collaborators in the exciting area of mobile data management. Finally, attendees had opportunities to listen to distinguished scientists explain the cutting edge of research across the breadth of mobile data management research.  Given the diversity of the research communities participating in MDM, attendees gained the opportunity to learn a new spectrum of technical and research results in the other communities.

After reimbursing the seven students for a total of  $8,590.60, we were left with a surplus of $11,409.40  (out of $20k budet). There are two reasons for this: 1) a small number of students applied for the award, and 2) some of the awardees did not utilize the entire allocated amount.  The leftover budget was returned to NSF.
